UPDATE: REMARKS ON COUNTABLE TIGHTNESS
MARION SCHEEPERS
Abstract. The proof of Theorem 11 of the paper [5] relies on Lemma 10
of that paper. The oered proof of Lemma 10 had shortcomings, and I was
recently asked for details. This note gives an alternative, complete proof of
[5], Lemma 10.
In [5] we considered the selection principle S1(A, B) for specic instances of
families A and B of sets. Recall that S1(A, B) denotes the statement that there
is for each sequence (On : n  N) of elements of A a corresponding sequence
(xn : n  N) such that for each n we have xn  On, and {xn : n  N}  B.
There is a natural game, denoted G1(A, B) associated with this selection princi-
ple: This two-player game is played as follows. There is an inning for each n  .
In inning n player ONE selects and On  A, and then TWO responds by selecting
an xn  On. A play (O0, x0,    , On, xn    ) is won by player TWO if the set
{xn : n  } is an element of the family B; else, the play is won by player ONE.
If player ONE does not have a winning strategy in the game G1(A, B), then the
selection principle S1(A, B) holds of the pair A, B. For many topological families A
and B it is the case that under appropriate circumstances also the converse holds:
The selection principle S1(A, B) implies that ONE has no winning strategy in the
game G1(A, B). Theorem 11 of [5] was intended to demonstrate an extreme case of
failure of this converse for well-studied examples of A and B.
More precisely: In [2] Sakai dened the notion of countable strong fan tightness
at the point x of a topological space (X,  ). This notion is dened as follows: For
the point x  X we dene
x = {A  X \ {x} : x is in the closure of A}.
Then (X,  ) is said to have countable strong fan tightness at x if the selection
principle S1(x, x) holds.
In [3] it was shown that for certain nice spaces (X,  ) it is true that S1(x, x)
holds if, and only if, ONE has now winning strategy in the game G1(x, x). In
[3] also an ad hoc example of the failure of this equivalence was given. In Theorem
11 of [5] the following more extreme example is given, assuming the Continuum
Hypothesis (CH):
Theorem 1 (CH). There is a T3 space X that has countable strong fan tightness
at each x  X, yet ONE has a winning strategy in G1(x, x) at each x  X.
Date: September 28, 2015.
2000 Mathematics Subject Classication. 54A35, 54D65.
Key words and phrases. Selection principle, countable strong fan tightness, innite game.
MARION SCHEEPERS
1. Lemma 10
For topological space (X,  ) let D denote the set {A  X : A dense in X}. Also,
let ND denote the set {A  X : A is not discrete}. In [5] the proof of Theorem 1
made use of a lemma regarding the innite game G1(D, ND). This game is a dual
version of a game introduced in [1] by Berner and Juhasz. More details about this
game and construction of the dual game appear in the sources [1, 4, 5].
The claimed proof ot Lemma 10 of [5] is awed. Here is a correct argument:
Lemma 2. Let (X,  ) be a T1-space with no isolated points. Assume that player
ONE has a winning strategy in the game G1(D, ND) on X. Then at each x  X
ONE has a winning strategy in the game G1(x, x).
Proof. Let  be a winning strategy for ONE in the game G1(D, ND). For each
x  X, dene a strategy x as follows:
for each nite sequence (w1,    , wn) of elements of X, x(w1,    , wn) =
Since X has no isolated points, for each dense set D  X and each x  X, the set
D\{x} is dense in X. Thus, x is a strategy for player ONE in the game G1(D, ND).
Each x play of the game G1(D, ND) is a -play during which TWO never picked
the element x. Thus, x is also a winning strategy for ONE in G1(D, ND).
Now we note that at each x  X the strategy x is a winning strategy for ONE
in the game G1(x, x): For consider a x-play
O1, w1, O2, w2,    , On, wn,
For each n, On is a dense set not containing the point x, and thus is an element of
x. The set {wn : 0  n  } is a discrete subset of X and does not contain the
point x. Thus, let U be a neighborhood of x meeting the set of moves by TWO in
at most one point, say wn. Since x 6= wn and X is T1, there is a neighborhood W
of x that does not contain wn. But then U  W is a neighborhood of x disjoint from
{wn : 0  n  }. It follows that {wn : 0  n  } is not an element of x.
